semantic_title: Two or More Interrelated Conditions for Principal Diagnosis - Sequencing Flexibility Rules
section_path: Section II > Selection of Principal Diagnosis > B. Two or more interrelated conditions, each potentially meeting the definition for principal diagnosis

content.full_text: When there are two or more interrelated conditions (such as diseases in the same ICD-10-CM chapter or manifestations characteristically associated with a certain disease) potentially meeting the definition of principal diagnosis, either condition may be sequenced first, unless the circumstances of the admission, the therapy provided, the Tabular List, or the Alphabetic Index indicate otherwise. (Evidence: pg no: 108, L103-L107)
content.summary: Guidelines for sequencing when multiple interrelated conditions could serve as principal diagnosis, allowing flexibility unless specific guidance indicates otherwise (Evidence: pg no: 108, L103-L107)
key_concepts: Interrelated conditions may include diseases in same ICD-10-CM chapter (Evidence: pg no: 108, L105)
Manifestations characteristically associated with certain diseases qualify (Evidence: pg no: 108, L105-L106)
Either condition may be sequenced first with exceptions (Evidence: pg no: 108, L106-L107)
Admission circumstances, therapy, or coding guidance may override flexibility (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Either interrelated condition may be sequenced first unless specific guidance indicates otherwise (Evidence: pg no: 108, L106-L107)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple interrelated conditions meet principal diagnosis criteria, coding flexibility exists unless overridden by admission circumstances, therapy provided, or coding instructions (Evidence: pg no: 108, L106-L107)
common_applications: Multiple conditions in same disease category

detailed_rules.rule_text: Admission circumstances, therapy, Tabular List, or Alphabetic Index may indicate specific sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)
detailed_rules.explanation: The general flexibility rule is overridden when specific factors provide clear guidance on sequencing priority (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify multiple conditions meeting principal diagnosis criteria
Step 2: Determine if conditions are interrelated
Step 3: Check admission circumstances for sequencing guidance
Step 4: Review therapy provided for sequencing clues
Step 5: Consult Tabular List and Alphabetic Index for specific instructions
Step 6: Apply flexibility rule if no specific guidance exists

code_patterns.description: Diseases within the same ICD-10-CM chapter that are interrelated (Evidence: pg no: 108, L105)
code_patterns.example: Multiple cardiovascular conditions, multiple respiratory conditions
code_patterns.explanation: Conditions in the same disease category that may be interrelated

code_patterns.description: Manifestations characteristically associated with certain diseases (Evidence: pg no: 108, L105-L106)
code_patterns.example: Diabetes with diabetic complications, hypertension with hypertensive complications
code_patterns.explanation: Primary disease with its characteristic manifestations

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted with diabetic ketoacidosis and uncontrolled diabetes
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted with diabetic ketoacidosis. Type 1 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled. Treated with insulin and fluid management.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify conditions (diabetic ketoacidosis, uncontrolled diabetes)
Step 2: Determine interrelationship (ketoacidosis is manifestation of diabetes)
Step 3: Review admission circumstances (ketoacidosis prompted admission)
Step 4: Consider therapy focus (ketoacidosis treatment priority)
Step 5: Apply sequencing based on admission circumstances

correct_coding.rationale: Admission circumstances and therapy focus indicate ketoacidosis as primary reason for admission (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would not reflect the specific reason for admission and treatment focus
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not considering admission circumstances when sequencing interrelated conditions

warnings: Must check for specific sequencing guidance before applying flexibility (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)
Admission circumstances always important in sequencing decisions (Evidence: pg no: 108, L107)
best_practices: Review all factors that might indicate specific sequencing
Consider the primary focus of treatment and care
Consult coding manuals for specific instructions
common_mistakes: Applying flexibility without checking for specific guidance
Ignoring admission circumstances in sequencing decisions
tips: Look for cause-and-effect relationships between conditions
Consider which condition required the inpatient level of care
Review therapy and treatment focus for sequencing clues
implementation_notes: Requires clinical understanding of disease relationships
Important to document rationale for sequencing choice
